Sir,-As know many of your readers " love fun," as your next will be published on the 1st of April, in the hope that l may contribute to the frol:cs of the day, and afford some useful hints to the admirers of practical jokes, on.!s first day of April last :-

 Got up early, and placing large basin of cold water close to my wife's side of the bed, laid down on the hearth-rug, and screamed ten thousand murders. Poor Betssy seeing me, as she thought, in dreadful agony, jumped out to my assist ance, when, popping both her feet into the basin slipped on her back, and was com pletely soused. Scrambled up laughing, and ran out crying April Fool" Rush- ed up stairs, and calling the cook, told her her mistress was in fit, aud desired her to go to her assistance. Down ran cooky cn ckcmise, and rushing into the
From Bells Life in London. THE FIRST OF APRIL.

Worthy of imitatiOn.-At the anniver- sary the Orphan Asylum society, held in the City Hetel, the 17th instant. little girl, apparently about 8 years of age, pre- ssnted an earthern jar, in which was an aperture for receiving money, and earnest .ly requested the ladies to break it, and count the money she had collected for the little orphans, since the last anniversary. ." No sooner said than done ;" when out flew sixpences and cents, to the amount of mine dOllars. Next followed the gentle man who has charge of the Minerva libra ry, with his annual tribute of cents collect ed in a similar manner for the use of his directory. On opening his box, siz dOI- lars aud ftycents were poured into the orphans treasury.-Ncv York Observer.

the table-Sworc it was fine strong spirit, and tried in vain to weaken it with water from the kettle. Got blind drunk, played the devil with the Turkey carpet, and I was obliged to send him home in coach. Slipped slyly up stairs, while my wife was gone to see all right in the kitchen, and made "apple pie" with the sheet by turn ing it up half way with the tail towards the head. Thought l should have died laughing to see her gettingin. Called me an old booby, and got out to make the bed again. Put out the candle, and got in myself, but found to my great dismay, that there were two sorts of bed-pies, for Betty had actually placed large hair pie under the clothes. into which jumped, but was very well content to find it noth- ing worse.

 .Yonrs, &c. AN OLD JOKER.

 There is perhaps no medical observation s'etter established none more generally con- Sirmed by the experience of the hest phys- clans CT aA ages and countries,' and none of Snore importance to the human family, than dhe fact tkat many of the most difficult and ancMrstsie consnMptiDns originate in neglected colds. 1ss climate SO variable as ours, where the changes of EhA weather are frequently sudden aEd unexpected, it requires more care and attention to guard against this dangerous enemy of Re, than most people imagine, or are able and willing to bestew. The bills of snortaiity exhftit tae melancholy fact that She proportion of deaths by this disease may he considered as abo,r five to one. Inasmuch then ss this fatal disease bids defiance 10 the skill ef the most learned physicians, it is a qualification to the proprietor that he is ena- bled to offer to those afflicted with it a geod- ey prospect of relief in that highly valuable vs'enedy the TegetaS!e Indsea Specifc.-The Indians are happy in their knowledge of med- Scal plants; governed wholly by experieSce, Sley are certain as to their effect, and it is said by sa author of great character, that true consumption is a disease pever known among thena. s

PRICE, of the city of Baltimore. dc hereby certify and declare, that I was for long time afflicted with severe cold, accom- panied with an almost incessant 'ceugh, aud pain in my breast and lungs; also spitfing of blood and puruient matter from the lungs, with night sweats and levers, and was much emaciated by the loss of appetite. rest, SSc. applied to several eminent physicians, and passed through course of medicine, but could obtaiH no relief and found myself fast Serging on tc a confirmed. consumption. Hay ing at length heard of the. many astonishing cures affected by the VegetQble Indian Specif- Sc, was induced to make trial of it, and found almost immediate relief, and my stsestored. continued it's use, improving fast, my sppe- site better, and all the symptoms of the di- sease daily diminishing, and in Q few weeks was completely cured, and have remained so for several months, and am now m better health and flesh than I have been for many years. l therefore with confidence, rccon1- mend the use of the Vegetable Indian. Spccif- ic to all who suffer under similar complaint, and as a safe, pleasant and etfectuai remedy for consumptions, and all diseases of the breas and lungs. W. PRICE.

 The celebrated Dr. Cullen has taught us that our first attention should be employed in watching the approach of the disease and preventing it's proceeding to an incurable state and in persons of consumptive habit, especially those born of consumptive parents, the slightest symptoms of approaching con- sumption at the consumrtiye period of life ought carefully to he attended to-"

This specific may always be given in safety-it is mild, pleasant to the taste, and is found par ticulariy useful in hypochondrical nervous & hysteiical diseases. PAPER RAGS,

! A

 but then I had my joke. Went into inc

 parlour, and seeing my brothers boots at

 the fire, dropped an egg in each. Was delighted to see him crack them both. and

 draw out his feet covered with yolk.

 Laughed heartily, and exclaimed April Fool" Threw his boot at nay head, but ducking, the iron heel smashed a pier glass. Who's the fool" cried Jem. Heat ed the handle of the poker, and told Molly to stir the fire. In ecstacies at seeing her drop it with about four inches of the skin

 off her fingers. Unfortunately, it fell on

 a valuable china plate, tiled with toast the former was broken and the latter spoil ed but then it was the lst of April. Look ed quite dcmure when my wife came to

 breakfast. Said nothing but drank my coffee. Thought it was quite bad. Took another cup, and complained, when Betsey

 consoled me, by observing, that it was the

 1st of April, and she thought little jail

 lop would do me good. Didn't relish such

 jokes. Heard an old Irish woman crying mackerel. Called her several times. Highly amused to see her turn round and and scream coming" Twigged me at last, aud flung her patien at the window,

 to the detriment of two squares. Wrote note to Alderman Gobble to dine with

 his friend Thompson who knew was in the country. Gobble took the bait, but unfortana'ely, finding Thomson abroad, he jus, '' dropped in" upon me at dinner time, and nearly dcloured whole dish ot smelts, which l had got as a treat for self and rib. Met Mrs. Williams. Asked her if she had hoard of her sons accident :? " Good God l! no," said she, in great a. larm :" what is it 2" He has broke--, " Broke what in the name of Heavan!" she shriekrd with increasing alarm. "Ifis walking stick" said I, and trotted on in a roar of laughter; but not knowing where was going, stepped into milk pail to the great injury of my black silk stockings, as well as to the annoyance of the vender,

 who called me all the fools she could lay

 her tongue to. Went into Batson's; cal

 led for bason of soup drank cmpted

 the ink bottles into the bason. and then

 asked the waiter how he could bring me

 such stuff He begged pardon, and left

 him to find out his mistake.-Sent my son. with bottle to Apothecares' Hall for

 sixpenny worth of pigeons milk. Came

 back in half an hour and said they had hnone made. Y" Where's the sixpence," |"

 said I. "I spent it in oranges, ? said the young rogue, and had the grin against

 mo. Brushing into my neighbor Davis,

 and toid him was sure there was a fire

 in his house. Dreadfally alarmed, he

 ran into every room on the premises, but

 returned with an assurance that was

 mistaken. Called him " April Fool" and

 bid him look into the kitchen. Sent Mol-

 ly to Spital square to seo master silk weaver roasted. Camo back in hurry, and said he was only < in stew" Vex- ed with Alderman GobblcF about the smelts. Asked him to takc glass of Ma- deira, and accidentally, on purpose, pour ed him out a glass of vinegar. Burst into snort of laughter to see his wry face.

 My own wine went the wrong way, andI

 was nearly choakcd. Filled a blind nut

 with cayenne pepper, and gave it my wife

 to crack. Had her second time. I 1 thought she would have spit out her eye teeth in getting rid of its effects. Knew my -brother's party, and had soaped the soles ofhis shoes. Was delighted to hear him bump down on the crupper, overhead.

 Went up to have my laugh, and found him crying with a sprained ancle, the soap having given him prime slide. Ran down to send for the doctor, but nobody believing l only meant to make them Y" April Fools" Went myself and came all haste back with doctor Bolus. Found

 cat tied by the tail to the knocker, kick ing up precious chatter. Couldn't go near for fear of my eyes. At last, she worked of her tail. and .bolted. Cook opened the door all consternation. Scrambled up stairs to my brothers room with Bolus at my heels, but he was not there. Came running down again; trod on some peas, hich my son Jack shad placed to overturn 'the maids, was lauhrhed forward like "A, and rose majesticaily with all the skin off my back. Limped into the drawing room, and found my brother had only been gannmoning. Made virtue of necessity, and laughed with tears in my eyes, and pains in my bones. Not done yet. Sent cook to the linnen-draper's for 2 yds.of ell wide packthread. Came back, and said, s.they ant got none so narrow" Had another hearty laugh; but changed my tone on old dripping coming back, and saying she had left the door a-jar while she was gone after the ell-vide packthrea

AnE OAOOOO NOuANAIkONs Twas on sunny April day,

 When every songster's tuneful lay

 Was heard in nt'wOod-noteS" wild and strong, From verdant grove, and bower, and lawn, A day, in short, as poets say, Each twig was rObed in silver spray, The air was ether, such as floats Where angels love to tune their notes; The Heavens were hung with dazzling blue, And tinged with every varying hue. Twas then the flowers Obeyed the call, Which summoned them tO Fairy HaU To nominate to Natures tribe,

 One o'er their welfare to preside. COnvened-the Tulip ope'd the meeting, To each she gave welcome greeting. Spoke of their present state, and cause, "Ext0ii'd the beauty of their laws, Which by elections yearly made, Crushed hurtful projects in the blade: Denounced intrigue, and hurled her bolts 'Gainst demagogues and rneddling dOIts; Proved that all fresh from natures hands, Twas theirs t obey the wise commands Which precedents so plainly told,

 We're laid by seigniors grave and old; That they should nominate Queen, To rule upon the May-day green. She ceased.-The Liiac's bluslling cheek, Told all that she would gladly speak i; She trembled so, as she stood there, Her fragrance filrd the ambient air; But raIlying force, she soon essayed, Anassaid Amanda was the maid, Whose laughing eye, and stately mein, Was made to r}ssc the May-day green. A murnlur hereupnl Was heard, Aud soon the HyaciaM appeared; Begg'd d pardon of the Lilac-said She lov'd alike her heart and head; But in a case like this, she would G Bear with her folly if she should Prefer sweet Annals form divine, To fair Amanda's graceful line. In this much speaking, pro and con, Was heard among the lovely thrOng. Each had her own opinion set, Formed and digested, ere they met; Each thought her candidate the best, Pre-eminent OCT. all the rest. Each party pledged them not to yield, And all contended for the field. Twas thus they stood, in high debate, A flowery phaianx, firm as Fate; When from among the bustllng crowd, Was heard voice not harsh or loud, But twas so soft, they thought the breeze, Had only shook the vcrdant trees; Each gazed upon the spot from whence The voice appeared.to strike the sense But ncught they saw till Zephyr's wing,, Swept OCT the Rose the breath Of Spring, And brought the Violet out to sight, Half dead with terror and alright.

 Observing that her lowly statiUA As Precluded envy's vic teinptation,

 She gently enid her sister flowers, For thus consuming Reeting hours; When each one knew that life was frail, And short liv'd as q iover's tale; .. ..- Disputing who should be the Queen, To grace the May day feast audgreen, When yet a fairer form and face, Than Anna or Amanda grace, a Was blended with as fine mein As ever ripped a May-day Queen, And Oh her eye, she said, displayed More than can e'cr be penn'd 0p said, And gave her face such beauty meek, 'TwOuld not disgrace cherub's cheek. With disposition pure and bland, AS Ger was joined ny Hymen's band. Hey voice was softcst '.music sent" From "Reason's governed instrument" She said that not much known to Fame, Helien was this fair maiden's name. HG SNOWY VMt EstOtCeF rose tO gay, She owned fair Hellens gentle sway, And beg'd that Lilac would agree ,.- To leave the field to Helen free She praised the e:Lflac's rosy hue, . Not that for faEors she would sue, But iattered with so sweet grace. That Lilac could not have the face, 'Gainst such suit to urge her claim; So sacrificed Amanda's name. The Hyacinth was stern and proud. She would not bend to serve the crowd; She was privileged flower, whose rest Was on the virgins heaving breast. She told them with sarcastic sheer To vote-the result she did not fear; The "question," "previous question" loud, Was heard among the anxious crowd: The Crocus caught the stirring strain, The Primrose flung it Der the plain. Narcissus joined the babbling throng, And '' Question" echoed bud and long. The Tulip thereupon arose,

 And called for all the "ayes and noes;'' But " viun Voce' now was heard, A voice which seldom ever erred, And loudly OCT the wellkin' swellin' Told that the candidate was Helen. T.

 From Bells Life in London.

 THE FIRST OF APRIL. Sir,-As I know many of your readers
From Mrs. COlUia's Weekly Messeager. THE CAUCUS NOMINATION.

uuuHr tHe ClOtneS. lnlo Wnlcn l jumped, but was very well content to find it noth- ing worse.

 DESCRIPTION OF MALTA. Ertract cf q letter from the Rev. EInatha,s

 Grtdtey, Missionary to the EGst, to one of the

 Editors cf the Ne,o- York ObserUer, dated SMYRNA, Jan. l6, 1927.

 MY DEAR SIR,-Rey. Mir. Brewer and mv- self, on our way to this place, were delayed month at Malta. Thatislaud appears to have. been, originally, barren rock |; but the in- dustry of man has transformed into highly cultivated garden; so that now, it supports. and has long supported, denser population than any other country.

 When viewed from the water, it appears to be sterile indeed. Scarcely any green thing, save here and there the deep shaded olive, is seen; but walls of stone rise one above an- other as far as the eye can extend. But when viewed from the interior, the scene is reversed. The most beautiful little fields then present themselves. falling one below another as thew recede, like the successive beds of slopinr garden, and all thckly clothed with clover wheat and barley. Many of thse fields areir 1rgated by means ofreseryOirs, aqueducts, and wheels for raising water. The others during the heat of the summer, hecome'a pgrched desert.

 In preparing these fields, the Maltese use a plough, like that which Virgil describes. It is drawn by heifers, with the yoke tied to their horns, s,---sometimes by horses, or bv mules, and not unfrequently by an OK and an ass yoked together. So

 In the less highly cultivated spots, sheep. and goats are seen grazing. The one is valued only for its hesh,-the other is prized for it's milk, and so highly, that cue of the largest size IS numbered among the inmates of most of the poorer families. - The donkey is chiefly used as the beast of burden ;--an animal SO small, and vet of such strength, as 10 diyest of all ahsurdity, that fa- ble of Esop, in which hs makes the miller and his son dismount, and carry upon their shoulders the animal on which they had been riding.

 Tbe caleshe, a heavy, two-wheeled vehicle, with single seat and closed top, is the car riage chiefly used. It is drawn by one horse, ' and the driver paces along by its side.--. Brides and stirraps are scarcely known in ' Malta. v.esa.a

 Thc buildings are all of hewn stone, ofa light yellow. and so soft asfo De easily shaped by edged stp0ls The roofs are flat, and fias- tered ose rith hard, firm, water proof cement. A"uoCS M tHe cIty dfc ScleFdity lafke anu ei- egant, Ornamented with much carved work, in which the Maltese excel, and have bal- comics in the upper stories, extending into the street.

 Valetta is the principal city, It is built up- on narrow peninsula, having an excellent harhor on each side. Its walls are high and strong, and it's foss@ deep. It is probably the strongest fortified city in ali the world. 1t is laid out with much regularity; the streets are wide, and we'll paved, and the sidewalks good. As there are no wells here, rain water IS carefully preserved in tanks dug deep in the rock. and it is scarcely inferior to water ftom the purest spring. There are also many pub lic reseEsoirs, into which streams are constant ly p01ring from the mouths of lions, eagles. swans, geese, and various other animals, beau tIfuily carved from stone. This is from an a. qyeduct, IS miles in length, onthe ancient Roman plan. It is covered canal, Ri of stone. carried upon level. and supported, ever val Ieys, by heavy stone arches. This stupendous work was the private munifcence Ofan individ- ual,--a Grand Master of the Knights of St. John. "

 The most magnificent edifce in Valetta, is St. Johns Church. It is @8O feet in front {; it's wings extend back 60 feet; and the main body Ofthe building 98O feet. 1t covers about IO6 square rods of ground, or twoAthirds of an acre. It has two spires, and eight or ten bells, some of which are very heayy. The pavement consists of about 800 sepulchral stones, of inlaid marble. of divers colors, each one of which must have been the work of ma. ny years. A number of these sepulchral mar bies are encrusted with Jasper, Agate, and other precious stones. and at an expense of no less than 5000 each. Six massive col ulns on each side support the arched roof- The columns extend back I7 feet, dividing both sides into alcoves. which communicate with each other by arched pathways. The walls are one entire piece of sculpture. From them stand out, in bold relief, military stand ards, lions, birds, deaths heads. angels and cherubims and over the whole is thrown gliding. The arched roof is covered with paintings, representing different events in the life of St. John. These are executed upon stucco,a ,and some of them have been pronoun- ced incomparably fine. Along each eide. from the top of the columns supporting this arch. are suspended pieces of tapestry, of great size. They are representations of various portions of ScnptUre history, and the execu- ton is almost to the life. They were wrought at an expenseo S9OO,O00 In the receasesOf the alcoyes, are paintings of the virgin. auhof saints, exqnisitely beautiful pieces of statu4Fy

They will he found, in all cases of the fol- lowing description, to give relief-nausea, vomiting, heartburn, costiVeness, weakness at the breast, pain in the stomach, loss of ap- petite, and all other simptOms of indigestion and flatulence, and as nervous cordial is not to be surpassed by any thing.-Price 6 cents a hOx

No sooner said than done ;" when out flew sixpences and cents, to the amount of mine dOllars. Next followed the gentle man who has charge of the Minerva libra ry, with his annual tribute of cents collect ed in a similar manner for the use of his directory. On opening his box, siz dOI- lars aud ftycents were poured into the orphans treasury.-Ncv York Observer.

the table-Sworc it was fine strong spirit, and tried in vain to weaken it with water from the kettle. Got blind drunk, played the devil with the Turkey carpet, and I was obliged to send him home in coach. Slipped slyly up stairs, while my wife was gone to see all right in the kitchen, and made "apple pie" with the sheet by turn ing it up half way with the tail towards the head. Thought l should have died laughing to see her gettingin. Called me an old booby, and got out to make the bed again. Put out the candle, and got in myself, but found to my great dismay, that there were two sorts of bed-pies, for Betty had actually placed large hair pie under the clothes. into which jumped, but was very well content to find it noth- ing worse.

 .Yonrs, &c. AN OLD JOKER.

ANDREW CHAPINsS ESTATE. TFSHE Court of Probate for the District of A Sharon has assigned the 9th day of June next at g o'clock A. M. at the Probate Office in Salisbury for the appointment of Commissioners upon the estate of

 ANDREW CHAPIM

 late of Wolcott, county of Wayne and State of New York, deceased, represented insolvent, when and where all persons interested may appear and be heard.

 By order of Court,

 PHINEAS CHAPIN, Admr. Salisbury, April 18th, 1897. 47

The bills of snortaiity exhftit tae melancholy fact that She proportion of deaths by this disease may he considered as abo,r five to one. Inasmuch then ss this fatal disease bids defiance 10 the skill ef the most learned physicians, it is a qualification to the proprietor that he is ena- bled to offer to those afflicted with it a geod- ey prospect of relief in that highly valuable vs'enedy the TegetaS!e Indsea Specifc.-The Indians are happy in their knowledge of med- Scal plants; governed wholly by experieSce, Sley are certain as to their effect, and it is said by sa author of great character, that true consumption is a disease pever known among thena. s

Hay ing at length heard of the. many astonishing cures affected by the VegetQble Indian Specif- Sc, was induced to make trial of it, and found almost immediate relief, and my stsestored. continued it's use, improving fast, my sppe- site better, and all the symptoms of the di- sease daily diminishing, and in Q few weeks was completely cured, and have remained so for several months, and am now m better health and flesh than I have been for many years. l therefore with confidence, rccon1- mend the use of the Vegetable Indian. Spccif- ic to all who suffer under similar complaint, and as a safe, pleasant and etfectuai remedy for consumptions, and all diseases of the breas and lungs. W. PRICE.

 The celebrated Dr. Cullen has taught us that our first attention should be employed in watching the approach of the disease and preventing it's proceeding to an incurable state and in persons of consumptive habit, especially those born of consumptive parents, the slightest symptoms of approaching con- sumption at the consumrtiye period of life ought carefully to he attended to-"

 The Specific is obtained by extraction from herbs, roots, flowers, plants, &c. when nper- lection. In this manner 1t removes the hectic fever, improves digestion, gives strength to the nerves. repairs the appetite and improves the spirits. full articles.headline: PAPER RAGS,
full articles.article:
WILL be received at this Office, in pay W ment for the County Post, in exchange for Books and Stationary, or will be bought with cash.

 bitchfefd, April II, 1897.

! A

 but then I had my joke. Went into inc

 parlour, and seeing my brothers boots at

 the fire, dropped an egg in each. Was delighted to see him crack them both. and

 draw out his feet covered with yolk.

 Laughed heartily, and exclaimed April Fool" Threw his boot at nay head, but ducking, the iron heel smashed a pier glass. Who's the fool" cried Jem. Heat ed the handle of the poker, and told Molly to stir the fire. In ecstacies at seeing her drop it with about four inches of the skin

 off her fingers. Unfortunately, it fell on

 a valuable china plate, tiled with toast the former was broken and the latter spoil ed but then it was the lst of April. Look ed quite dcmure when my wife came to

 breakfast. Said nothing but drank my coffee. Thought it was quite bad. Took another cup, and complained, when Betsey

 consoled me, by observing, that it was the

 1st of April, and she thought little jail

 lop would do me good. Didn't relish such

 jokes. Heard an old Irish woman crying mackerel. Called her several times. Highly amused to see her turn round and and scream coming" Twigged me at last, aud flung her patien at the window,

 to the detriment of two squares. Wrote note to Alderman Gobble to dine with

 his friend Thompson who knew was in the country. Gobble took the bait, but unfortana'ely, finding Thomson abroad, he jus, '' dropped in" upon me at dinner time, and nearly dcloured whole dish ot smelts, which l had got as a treat for self and rib. Met Mrs. Williams. Asked her if she had hoard of her sons accident :? " Good God l! no," said she, in great a. larm :" what is it 2" He has broke--, " Broke what in the name of Heavan!" she shriekrd with increasing alarm. "Ifis walking stick" said I, and trotted on in a roar of laughter; but not knowing where was going, stepped into milk pail to the great injury of my black silk stockings, as well as to the annoyance of the vender,

 who called me all the fools she could lay

 her tongue to. Went into Batson's; cal

 led for bason of soup drank cmpted

 the ink bottles into the bason. and then

 asked the waiter how he could bring me

 such stuff He begged pardon, and left

 him to find out his mistake.-Sent my son. with bottle to Apothecares' Hall for

 sixpenny worth of pigeons milk. Came

 back in half an hour and said they had hnone made. Y" Where's the sixpence," |"

 said I. "I spent it in oranges, ? said the young rogue, and had the grin against

 mo. Brushing into my neighbor Davis,

 and toid him was sure there was a fire

 in his house. Dreadfally alarmed, he

 ran into every room on the premises, but

 returned with an assurance that was

 mistaken. Called him " April Fool" and

 bid him look into the kitchen. Sent Mol-

 ly to Spital square to seo master silk weaver roasted. Camo back in hurry, and said he was only < in stew" Vex- ed with Alderman GobblcF about the smelts. Asked him to takc glass of Ma- deira, and accidentally, on purpose, pour ed him out a glass of vinegar. Burst into snort of laughter to see his wry face.

 My own wine went the wrong way, andI

 was nearly choakcd. Filled a blind nut

 with cayenne pepper, and gave it my wife

 to crack. Had her second time. I 1 thought she would have spit out her eye teeth in getting rid of its effects. Knew my -brother's party, and had soaped the soles ofhis shoes. Was delighted to hear him bump down on the crupper, overhead.

 Went up to have my laugh, and found him crying with a sprained ancle, the soap having given him prime slide. Ran down to send for the doctor, but nobody believing l only meant to make them Y" April Fools" Went myself and came all haste back with doctor Bolus. Found

 cat tied by the tail to the knocker, kick ing up precious chatter. Couldn't go near for fear of my eyes. At last, she worked of her tail. and .bolted. Cook opened the door all consternation. Scrambled up stairs to my brothers room with Bolus at my heels, but he was not there. Came running down again; trod on some peas, hich my son Jack shad placed to overturn 'the maids, was lauhrhed forward like "A, and rose majesticaily with all the skin off my back. Limped into the drawing room, and found my brother had only been gannmoning. Made virtue of necessity, and laughed with tears in my eyes, and pains in my bones. Not done yet. Sent cook to the linnen-draper's for 2 yds.of ell wide packthread. Came back, and said, s.they ant got none so narrow" Had another hearty laugh; but changed my tone on old dripping coming back, and saying she had left the door a-jar while she was gone after the ell-vide packthrea

full articles.headline: From Mrs. COlUia's Weekly Messeager. THE CAUCUS NOMINATION.
full articles.article:
AnE OAOOOO NOuANAIkONs Twas on sunny April day,

 When every songster's tuneful lay

 Was heard in nt'wOod-noteS" wild and strong, From verdant grove, and bower, and lawn, A day, in short, as poets say, Each twig was rObed in silver spray, The air was ether, such as floats Where angels love to tune their notes; The Heavens were hung with dazzling blue, And tinged with every varying hue. Twas then the flowers Obeyed the call, Which summoned them tO Fairy HaU To nominate to Natures tribe,

 One o'er their welfare to preside. COnvened-the Tulip ope'd the meeting, To each she gave welcome greeting. Spoke of their present state, and cause, "Ext0ii'd the beauty of their laws, Which by elections yearly made, Crushed hurtful projects in the blade: Denounced intrigue, and hurled her bolts 'Gainst demagogues and rneddling dOIts; Proved that all fresh from natures hands, Twas theirs t obey the wise commands Which precedents so plainly told,

 We're laid by seigniors grave and old; That they should nominate Queen, To rule upon the May-day green. She ceased.-The Liiac's bluslling cheek, Told all that she would gladly speak i; She trembled so, as she stood there, Her fragrance filrd the ambient air; But raIlying force, she soon essayed, Anassaid Amanda was the maid, Whose laughing eye, and stately mein, Was made to r}ssc the May-day green. A murnlur hereupnl Was heard, Aud soon the HyaciaM appeared; Begg'd d pardon of the Lilac-said She lov'd alike her heart and head; But in a case like this, she would G Bear with her folly if she should Prefer sweet Annals form divine, To fair Amanda's graceful line. In this much speaking, pro and con, Was heard among the lovely thrOng. Each had her own opinion set, Formed and digested, ere they met; Each thought her candidate the best, Pre-eminent OCT. all the rest. Each party pledged them not to yield, And all contended for the field. Twas thus they stood, in high debate, A flowery phaianx, firm as Fate; When from among the bustllng crowd, Was heard voice not harsh or loud, But twas so soft, they thought the breeze, Had only shook the vcrdant trees; Each gazed upon the spot from whence The voice appeared.to strike the sense But ncught they saw till Zephyr's wing,, Swept OCT the Rose the breath Of Spring, And brought the Violet out to sight, Half dead with terror and alright.

 Observing that her lowly statiUA As Precluded envy's vic teinptation,

 She gently enid her sister flowers, For thus consuming Reeting hours; When each one knew that life was frail, And short liv'd as q iover's tale; .. ..- Disputing who should be the Queen, To grace the May day feast audgreen, When yet a fairer form and face, Than Anna or Amanda grace, a Was blended with as fine mein As ever ripped a May-day Queen, And Oh her eye, she said, displayed More than can e'cr be penn'd 0p said, And gave her face such beauty meek, 'TwOuld not disgrace cherub's cheek. With disposition pure and bland, AS Ger was joined ny Hymen's band. Hey voice was softcst '.music sent" From "Reason's governed instrument" She said that not much known to Fame, Helien was this fair maiden's name. HG SNOWY VMt EstOtCeF rose tO gay, She owned fair Hellens gentle sway, And beg'd that Lilac would agree ,.- To leave the field to Helen free She praised the e:Lflac's rosy hue, . Not that for faEors she would sue, But iattered with so sweet grace. That Lilac could not have the face, 'Gainst such suit to urge her claim; So sacrificed Amanda's name. The Hyacinth was stern and proud. She would not bend to serve the crowd; She was privileged flower, whose rest Was on the virgins heaving breast. She told them with sarcastic sheer To vote-the result she did not fear; The "question," "previous question" loud, Was heard among the anxious crowd: The Crocus caught the stirring strain, The Primrose flung it Der the plain. Narcissus joined the babbling throng, And '' Question" echoed bud and long. The Tulip thereupon arose,

 And called for all the "ayes and noes;'' But " viun Voce' now was heard, A voice which seldom ever erred, And loudly OCT the wellkin' swellin' Told that the candidate was Helen. T.

 From Bells Life in London.

 THE FIRST OF APRIL. Sir,-As I know many of your readers

uuuHr tHe ClOtneS. lnlo Wnlcn l jumped, but was very well content to find it noth- ing worse.

 ,Yonrs, &c. ANOLD JOKER.

 DESCRIPTION OF MALTA. Ertract cf q letter from the Rev. EInatha,s

 Grtdtey, Missionary to the EGst, to one of the

 Editors cf the Ne,o- York ObserUer, dated SMYRNA, Jan. l6, 1927.

 MY DEAR SIR,-Rey. Mir. Brewer and mv- self, on our way to this place, were delayed month at Malta. Thatislaud appears to have. been, originally, barren rock |; but the in- dustry of man has transformed into highly cultivated garden; so that now, it supports. and has long supported, denser population than any other country.

 When viewed from the water, it appears to be sterile indeed. Scarcely any green thing, save here and there the deep shaded olive, is seen; but walls of stone rise one above an- other as far as the eye can extend. But when viewed from the interior, the scene is reversed. The most beautiful little fields then present themselves. falling one below another as thew recede, like the successive beds of slopinr garden, and all thckly clothed with clover wheat and barley. Many of thse fields areir 1rgated by means ofreseryOirs, aqueducts, and wheels for raising water. The others during the heat of the summer, hecome'a pgrched desert.

 In preparing these fields, the Maltese use a plough, like that which Virgil describes. It is drawn by heifers, with the yoke tied to their horns, s,---sometimes by horses, or bv mules, and not unfrequently by an OK and an ass yoked together. So

 In the less highly cultivated spots, sheep. and goats are seen grazing. The one is valued only for its hesh,-the other is prized for it's milk, and so highly, that cue of the largest size IS numbered among the inmates of most of the poorer families. - The donkey is chiefly used as the beast of burden ;--an animal SO small, and vet of such strength, as 10 diyest of all ahsurdity, that fa- ble of Esop, in which hs makes the miller and his son dismount, and carry upon their shoulders the animal on which they had been riding.

 Tbe caleshe, a heavy, two-wheeled vehicle, with single seat and closed top, is the car riage chiefly used. It is drawn by one horse, ' and the driver paces along by its side.--. Brides and stirraps are scarcely known in ' Malta. v.esa.a

 Thc buildings are all of hewn stone, ofa light yellow. and so soft asfo De easily shaped by edged stp0ls The roofs are flat, and fias- tered ose rith hard, firm, water proof cement. A"uoCS M tHe cIty dfc ScleFdity lafke anu ei- egant, Ornamented with much carved work, in which the Maltese excel, and have bal- comics in the upper stories, extending into the street.

 Valetta is the principal city, It is built up- on narrow peninsula, having an excellent harhor on each side. Its walls are high and strong, and it's foss@ deep. It is probably the strongest fortified city in ali the world. 1t is laid out with much regularity; the streets are wide, and we'll paved, and the sidewalks good. As there are no wells here, rain water IS carefully preserved in tanks dug deep in the rock. and it is scarcely inferior to water ftom the purest spring. There are also many pub lic reseEsoirs, into which streams are constant ly p01ring from the mouths of lions, eagles. swans, geese, and various other animals, beau tIfuily carved from stone. This is from an a. qyeduct, IS miles in length, onthe ancient Roman plan. It is covered canal, Ri of stone. carried upon level. and supported, ever val Ieys, by heavy stone arches. This stupendous work was the private munifcence Ofan individ- ual,--a Grand Master of the Knights of St. John. "

 The most magnificent edifce in Valetta, is St. Johns Church. It is @8O feet in front {; it's wings extend back 60 feet; and the main body Ofthe building 98O feet. 1t covers about IO6 square rods of ground, or twoAthirds of an acre. It has two spires, and eight or ten bells, some of which are very heayy. The pavement consists of about 800 sepulchral stones, of inlaid marble. of divers colors, each one of which must have been the work of ma. ny years. A number of these sepulchral mar bies are encrusted with Jasper, Agate, and other precious stones. and at an expense of no less than 5000 each. Six massive col ulns on each side support the arched roof- The columns extend back I7 feet, dividing both sides into alcoves. which communicate with each other by arched pathways. The walls are one entire piece of sculpture. From them stand out, in bold relief, military stand ards, lions, birds, deaths heads. angels and cherubims and over the whole is thrown gliding. The arched roof is covered with paintings, representing different events in the life of St. John. These are executed upon stucco,a ,and some of them have been pronoun- ced incomparably fine. Along each eide. from the top of the columns supporting this arch. are suspended pieces of tapestry, of great size. They are representations of various portions of ScnptUre history, and the execu- ton is almost to the life. They were wrought at an expenseo S9OO,O00 In the receasesOf the alcoyes, are paintings of the virgin. auhof saints, exqnisitely beautiful pieces of statu4Fy
